title.narrative: Resources of Hope: Giving voice to underprivileged communities in India

description.narrative: Responding to the International Development Highlight Notice, Resources of Hope will work with three leading India-based collaborators to: a. use artistic methods of storytelling and knowledge production with people in two sectors of Indian society to articulate and build their hopes for obtaining their rights to food, housing and democratic participation under the Indian constitution. b. create capacity for knowledge exchange between leading researchers and NGOs in the UK and India in the field of participatory use of multi-media, particularly in contexts of high deprivation and gender inequality. c. improve the practice of community-led creativity, both in UK-based and Indian development agencies. d. contribute to cultural and policy change that sees democratising access to knowledge and valuing expertise gained through experience as a vital means of implementing the UN's Sustainable Development Goals. To achieve these aims, Resources of Hope will: 1. establish two "Art-mix" Groups events with our collaborators in Dharavi (ACORN Foundation) and Telangana (Yakshi). Each group will bring together ten grassroots community artists, the majority of them women, who will critically assess their representation in media that influences the policies of the state, international philanthropic groups and other agencies. 2. provide training for them to document their analysis through storytelling, performance and film in order to generate a larger-scale debate both in their community and with policy-makers via two Art-max Festivals. 3. collaborate with community activists and our project collaborators to develop advocacy strategies for policy change, particularly relating to the constitutional right to food, control over land and participation in decisions that directly affect quality of life (as specified in the UN's 2015 Sustainable Development Goals - SDGs). 4. provide the cultural tools and expertise to produce counter-narratives that challenge media representations and taken for granted 'othering' of underprivileged classes and castes.
